title: EPIRETINAL MEMBRANES: A Comprehensive Clinical Guide
summary: An exhaustive visual guide to Epiretinal Membranes (ERM), detailing synonyms, pathogenesis, and clinical features. It covers advanced surgical interventions, prognostic factors, and the comprehensive list of secondary causes including retinal insults and vascular disease.

sections.title: Epidemiology & Prevalence
content: Condition is commoner with increasing age.
Thought to be related to PVD.
Discussion applies mainly to the idiopathic form.

sections.title: Pathogenesis
content: 3. Cells migrate through defects in the Internal Limiting Membrane (ILM).
4. ILM defects arise most commonly during PVD.

sections.title: Clinical Features
content: Appearance: Membrane may be transparent (look for glistening light reflex), translucent, or white.
Vascular/Structural: Retinal striae; vessels may be tortuous, straightened, or obscured; pseudohole.
NB: The features are well demonstrated on red-free light.

rows: Confirms diagnosis; differentiates pseudo- vs true hole; compares pre- and post-operative status. Severity doesn't correlate with VA.
Seldom used now due to OCT; nicely demonstrates vascular abnormalities and any associated CMO.

sections.title: Treatment Indications & Surgery
content: Assessment: Ensure macular function is not limited by additional underlying pathology (e.g. ischaemia due to a vein occlusion).
Dye Visualization: Surgeons assist visualization by staining with ILM blue, membrane dual and brilliant blue G.
Safety Note: Due to concerns about retinal toxicity, previous dyes such as ICG are not generally used.

sections.title: Double Stain Technique
sections.content: A double stain technique to peel the ERM and ILM has reduced the recurrence rate of the ERM by removing the ILM that acts as a scaffold for proliferating cells. Reference: 17 Shimada H et al. Double staining with brilliant blue G and double peeling for epiretinal membrane. Ophthalmology. 2009;116:1370–6. E PIRETI n AL m E m BRA n ES 549

rows: No further reduction in VA after diagnosis.

content.explanation: Duration of symptoms before surgery; Underlying macular pathology; Lower preoperative acuity (though significant improvement may still occur).
